#Text=Be Safe in an Apartment
#Text=Security and safety are the two most common concerns for anyone around others .
#Text=Whether you 're taking public transportation , taking a stroll on a pathway , or even when you 're not home , you always have to keep yourself , your loved ones , and your belongings safe .
#Text=Residing in an apartment complex to some , especially college students not deciding to live in a dorm , might be an excitement time in their life to have their own place .
#Text=However , safety and security still needs to be applied at all times , especially when you are living with someone new .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Try to draft out security questions to your apartment/property manager when you first move in .
#Text=There may be security information on your lease papers , but questioning them would always provide answers to your specific questions .
#Text=Know the security of the main apartment entrance(s) .
#Text=Do you need specific keys , as a tenant , to enter ?
#Text=How many entrances are there ?
#Text=What are the hours at night when the hallway lights go on and turn off ?
#Text=Are there any hours of the amenities ( laundromat , pool , weight room , etc ) ?
#Text=Note down whom is responsible of the street lights in and around the property or parking lot .
#Text=Usually , it 's either the property manager or your local electric company .
#Text=Keep a list of numbers available if a light is broken or needs repairing .
#Text=Ask them whom enters the building that does not need a key or badge .
#Text=Common people may include the mail carrier and apartment maintenance .
#Text=Investigate the security of your apartment .
#Text=If there are no deadbolts or peepholes on your doors , request them from your property manager .
#Text=Decide on getting shades or blinds for all windows that do n't reflect inside activity that can be seen from the outside .

#Text=You can also consider moving your television away from the window view ; this would deter on-lookers on the size of the television reflection/motion , as a person can easily calculate how big the screen is .
#Text=Make sure that all of your windows securely lock properly , even if you do n't live on the ground level .
#Text=Keep a written schedule or reminders of events .
#Text=If you 're expecting a package through a company aside from the postal office , jot down the estimated date of arrival .
#Text=Schedule all appointments , such as cable/internet company , electric , or other necessary needs at a specific date and time .
#Text=Be sure that you get identification prior to allowing them in , even if it 's having them slide a badge under the door if there is n't a peephole available .

#Text=Times throughout the year , the property manager is required to check the maintenance of the overall building and your own apartment , such as proper lighting , smoke detectors , and apartment inspections .
#Text=Usually a note to all tenants will be posted somewhere near the main entrance or mailboxes prior to the intended date .
#Text=They may also need a secondary person to assist with assignments , so thoroughly read any notices to be aware of the situation .
#Text=Be secretive concerning the mailbox .
#Text=When a tenant first moves in , they need to label their individual mail slot .
#Text=Use only your last name at all times , as this is enough identification to your mail carrier .
#Text=If you happen to receive mail that appears as if it belongs to a previous tenant ( different name , same apartment number ) , never manipulate nor destroy the item .
#Text=Always write " Not at this address " on the envelope and drop/return it at any mail receptacle .
#Text=Report any issues inside the building to your property manager .

#Text=They are responsible for keeping the buildings(s) secured and maintained , however , if you see any lock tampering or lights that goes out for a period of time , give them a heads up as soon as possible .
#Text=Weather and seasons also affect maintenance , for example , any ice/dirt build-up or any extremely high wind impact on the doors may not keep them completely shut and locked .
#Text=Be careful on how and whom you notify when leaving your apartment .
#Text=Never , under any circumstances , leave short notes on your doors for any roommates or others that reside with you .
#Text=You will never know who is around while you 're gone .
#Text=Always give the intended party a short call or text message letting them know your whereabouts , even if it 's a short trip to the store .
#Text=Always contact nearby family and friends when planning on leaving for a longer time duration , including any out of state departures .
#Text=Do n't allow them to have any keys for the building , but allow them to check on any suspicious behavior in the area .
#Text=Protect your car as much as you protect yourself .
#Text=Never leave your valuables inside of your car , especially in places where people can take a quick glimpse from the window to see what 's inside .
#Text=Always lock all doors , even if you forgot something inside your apartment .
#Text=If you 're defrosting your car during the winter , stay with it at all times while its running .
#Text=The best opportunity for a thief is when they see an unattended car with the engine on .
#Text=Get to know your neighbors .
#Text=Even if it 's their first names , it 'll give you a sense of security of knowing those living around you .
#Text=Offer a hand to your elderly neighbors , such as carrying groceries from their car .
#Text=Living in a very small complex may allow tenants to interact with each other in a more secured way than people whom reside in a building with many tenants .
#Text=Treat their packages left outside like your own and leave it by their doorstep instead of ignoring it as you pass by .
